notAlone.title: You're Not Alone in This Journey üíô
notAlone.content: Navigating puberty with your child can feel challenging, but you're doing great! This app provides evidence-based guidance, practical tips, and interactive activities to help you support your child with confidence and compassion. Remember: open communication and unconditional love are your greatest tools.

welcome.universityMessage: Powered with heart by the University of Malaya community‚Äîuniting research, creativity, and compassion for families.

slide1.title: Welcome, Dear Parent! üíù
slide1.subtitle: We're So Glad You're Here
slide1.description: Parenting through puberty can feel overwhelming, but you don't have to navigate it alone. This app is designed with love to support YOU in supporting your child through one of life's most significant transitions. Together, we'll make this journey smoother for your whole family.

slide2.title: Understanding Your Role
slide2.subtitle: You're Your Child's Most Important Guide
slide2.description: Your child needs your wisdom, patience, and unconditional support more than ever. This app helps you understand what they're experiencing physically and emotionally, so you can provide the guidance they need while respecting their growing independence and privacy.

slide3.title: What This App Offers
slide3.subtitle: Everything You Need in One Place
slide3.feature1: Expert parenting guidance on communication and emotional support
slide3.feature2: Educational games and activities for your child
slide3.feature3: Age-appropriate information about physical and emotional changes
slide3.feature4: AI-powered assistant to answer your parenting questions
slide3.feature5: Private diary space for your child to process their feelings

slide4.title: Your Privacy & Safety Matter
slide4.subtitle: We Take Your Trust Seriously
slide4.point1: All data stays on your device - nothing is sent to external servers
slide4.point2: No tracking, no analytics, no third-party access to your information
slide4.point3: The diary feature is completely private - only your child can access their entries
slide4.point4: This is a safe, judgment-free space designed with child safety and family privacy as top priorities
slide4.acceptPrivacy: I understand and accept the privacy policy

aiChat.title: Parent Assistant
aiChat.subtitle: Ask me anything about puberty (English, ÿßŸÑÿπÿ±ÿ®Ÿäÿ©, Bahasa Melayu)
aiChat.greeting: Hi there! I'm your Parenting Hub guide. Share any parenting worry and I'll connect you with steps, activities, and reassurance.
aiChat.greetingTips: Ask about starting the puberty talk.|Get ideas for supporting big emotions.|Discover activities your child will actually enjoy.

suggestions.q1: How do I start the puberty conversation?
suggestions.q2: How can I support my child's emotions?
suggestions.q3: What activities can help my child?
suggestions.q4: How do I handle mood swings?
suggestions.q5: How do I talk about new hygiene needs?
suggestions.q6: My child feels anxious‚Äîwhat can I do?

aiChat.footerMessage: Parenting Hub answers are handcrafted guidance in English, ÿßŸÑÿπÿ±ÿ®Ÿäÿ©, and Bahasa Melayu.

tips.normalize: Start by normalizing puberty as something everyone experiences.|Speak in short, everyday chats instead of one big talk.
tips.useMoments: Use TV scenes, books, or shared routines as natural conversation openers.|Let your child know they can revisit the topic anytime.
tips.activeListening: Put away distractions and make eye contact.|Reflect back what you hear so your child feels truly understood.
tips.doorOpen: Remind your child you are available for quick questions anytime.|Invite them to text or leave notes if talking face-to-face feels hard.
tips.emotionToolkit: Offer calming tools like breathing exercises or short walks.|Help them label feelings‚Äînaming emotions reduces their intensity.
tips.validate: Let them know mood swings are normal during puberty.|Thank them for trusting you with their feelings.
tips.friendship: Discuss what supportive friendships look like.|Encourage them to notice how they feel after spending time with friends.
tips.rolePlay: Practice boundary-setting phrases together.|Brainstorm responses to tricky peer situations.
tips.privacyExplain: Explain how the app protects their diary entries locally.|Assure them you respect their growing need for personal space.
tips.space: Balance guidance with privacy‚Äîknock before entering rooms.|Agree on check-in moments that feel comfortable for both of you.
tips.coLearning: Play one of our games together and talk about the answers.|Share your own thoughts so learning feels like teamwork.
tips.celebrate: Celebrate curiosity‚Äîsmall high-fives go a long way.|Ask what they enjoyed most after each activity.
tips.routine: Create a simple hygiene checklist for mornings and evenings.|Stock essentials like deodorant and gentle skincare products together.
tips.products: Let your child choose products that match their style.|Teach how to wash clothes and care for their body with confidence.
tips.balancedPlate: Build plates with veggies, protein, and whole grains.|Keep healthy snacks ready for fast-growing bodies.
tips.familyMeals: Plan family meals where everyone helps with prep.|Talk about how food fuels energy, mood, and focus.
tips.sleepHygiene: Keep a consistent bedtime and calming wind-down routine.|Dim lights and limit heavy meals close to bedtime.
tips.screenTime: Power down screens 30 minutes before sleep.|Charge devices outside the bedroom when possible.
tips.calming: Teach calming breaths, stretching, or journaling for anxious moments.|Notice triggers together and create a soothing plan.
tips.seekSupport: If worry feels heavy, connect with school counselors or healthcare providers.|Remind your child they never have to carry big feelings alone.
tips.listenFirst: Listen fully before responding so they feel safe opening up.|Thank them for trusting you with their experience.
tips.schoolSupport: Document incidents and loop in teachers or counselors early.|Practice confident responses and plan safe exit strategies.
tips.teamSpirit: Explore different sections of Parenting Hub together.|Share what is working so we can keep improving for your family.
tips.stayCurious: No question is too small‚Äîkeep asking and we‚Äôll keep supporting.|Switch languages anytime for the wording that feels right.

response.puberty: You‚Äôre doing amazing by opening this door. Puberty chats land best when they‚Äôre short, warm, and ongoing. Remind your child that every body grows at its own pace and you‚Äôre beside them for every question.
response.communication: Trust is built in the quiet moments. Listen with full attention, invite their perspective, and thank them for sharing‚Äîeven when it‚Äôs messy. Your calm presence is the anchor they need.
response.emotions: Big feelings are part of growing up. Help your child spot patterns, name emotions, and experiment with healthy outlets like movement, art, or journaling. Celebrate their honesty every time they reach out.
response.social: Friendships can shift quickly during puberty. Talk about what respect, joy, and safety look like in relationships. Role-play tricky moments so they feel prepared to stand up for themselves and others.
response.privacy: Great question! Parenting Hub stores information safely on your device only. Encourage your child to enjoy the private diary while knowing you‚Äôre nearby for support whenever they ask.
response.activities: Playful learning sticks! Visit our Games section for quizzes, matching games, and emotion adventures you can explore together. Follow up with a quick chat about what surprised them.
response.hygiene: Body changes can feel awkward‚Äîkeep it practical and light. Build a fresh routine together, stock supplies they like, and cheer each small win so hygiene becomes a confidence booster.
response.nutrition: Growing bodies crave steady fuel. Offer colorful plates, involve your child in meal prep, and connect foods to energy, mood, and focus. Small shifts beat perfect diets.
response.sleep: Rest is the quiet superpower. Create soothing bedtime cues, reduce screens before sleep, and protect their rest like it‚Äôs an important appointment.
response.anxiety: Worry shows up when life feels uncertain. Sit beside your child, breathe together, and co-create a calming plan. If the weight feels heavy, loop in school or health professionals for extra care.
response.bullying: No child should face bullying alone. Listen without rushing, document what happened, and partner with school staff. Rehearse assertive responses and remind your child they have a team behind them.
response.default: I‚Äôm here whenever you need a confident nudge. Ask about body changes, mental health, cultural traditions, or how to use our tools‚Äîand I‚Äôll keep bringing you practical next steps.

q1.question: Which of these is a normal part of puberty?

q3.question: When you have questions about puberty, what should you do?

matching.description: Match puberty changes with helpful ways to handle them
matching.instructions: Connect each change on the left with the best way to handle it on the right!

emotions.title: Understanding Emotions
emotions.description: Learn to identify and understand different emotions during puberty
emotions.instructions: Read each scenario and choose how it would make you feel!

scenario1.situation: Your friend borrowed your favorite thing without asking.

scenario2.situation: You worked really hard and got a great grade on your test!

scenario3.situation: You have to give a presentation in front of the whole class tomorrow.

parentGuide.title: Comprehensive Parent Guide
parentGuide.subtitle: Evidence-based advice to help you support your child through puberty üíô

startEarly.title: Start Conversations Early
startEarly.description: Don't wait for 'the talk' - make puberty an ongoing conversation
startEarly.tip1: Begin age-appropriate discussions around age 8-9, before changes start
startEarly.tip2: Use everyday moments as teaching opportunities (TV shows, books, observations)
startEarly.tip3: Keep conversations casual and normalize the topic - avoid making it feel like a big deal
startEarly.tip4: Let your child lead with questions and follow their curiosity

listening.title: Practice Active Listening
listening.description: Truly hearing your child builds trust and openness
listening.tip1: Put away phones and give undivided attention when they want to talk
listening.tip2: Don't interrupt or rush to fix problems - sometimes they just need to be heard
listening.tip3: Reflect back what you hear: 'It sounds like you're feeling...'
listening.tip4: Avoid judgment or dismissing their concerns, even if they seem small to you

openness.title: Create a Judgment-Free Zone
openness.description: Make it safe for your child to share anything with you
openness.tip1: Stay calm when they share difficult things - your reaction determines if they'll share again
openness.tip2: Share age-appropriate stories from your own puberty to show understanding
openness.tip3: Use correct anatomical terms - it removes shame and teaches proper language
openness.tip4: Reassure them that no question is too embarrassing or stupid to ask

moodSwings.title: Understanding Mood Swings
moodSwings.description: Hormonal changes cause real emotional turbulence - it's not just attitude
moodSwings.tip1: Recognize that mood swings are caused by biology, not intentional bad behavior
moodSwings.tip2: Don't take emotional outbursts personally - give space but stay available
moodSwings.tip3: Help them identify emotions: 'You seem frustrated' rather than 'Why are you so angry?'
moodSwings.tip4: Teach coping strategies: deep breathing, physical activity, journaling, or talking

confidence.title: Building Self-Confidence
confidence.description: Puberty can shake self-esteem - your support is crucial
confidence.tip1: Focus on effort and character traits, not just appearance or achievements
confidence.tip2: Point out their strengths regularly, especially in areas they might not notice
confidence.tip3: Model positive self-talk and body acceptance in your own life
confidence.tip4: Help them set realistic goals and celebrate small wins along the way

mentalHealth.title: Watch for Mental Health Concerns
mentalHealth.description: Know when normal mood changes cross into something more serious
mentalHealth.tip1: Persistent sadness lasting more than 2 weeks may indicate depression - seek help
mentalHealth.tip2: Watch for changes in sleep, appetite, grades, or withdrawal from activities they loved
mentalHealth.tip3: Take any mention of self-harm or suicidal thoughts extremely seriously - get immediate help
mentalHealth.tip4: There's no shame in professional help - therapists can provide tools you can't

bodyChanges.title: Explaining Physical Changes
bodyChanges.description: Help your child understand what's happening to their body
bodyChanges.tip1: Explain that everyone develops at different rates - there's no 'normal' timeline
bodyChanges.tip2: Discuss changes before they happen when possible - preparation reduces anxiety
bodyChanges.tip3: Be matter-of-fact about topics like periods, erections, and body hair
bodyChanges.tip4: Reassure them that awkward feelings about their changing body are temporary

hygiene.title: Teaching Proper Hygiene
hygiene.description: New hygiene needs arise during puberty
hygiene.tip1: Provide necessary products without fuss: deodorant, shampoo, menstrual supplies, etc.
hygiene.tip2: Teach daily showering, especially after sports or physical activity
hygiene.tip3: Discuss acne care gently - don't make them feel self-conscious
hygiene.tip4: Make hygiene supplies easily accessible in their bathroom space

health.title: Promoting Healthy Habits
health.description: Puberty is the perfect time to establish lifelong healthy behaviors
health.tip1: Ensure 8-10 hours of sleep nightly - teens need more sleep than you might think
health.tip2: Stock healthy snacks - growing bodies need good fuel frequently
health.tip3: Encourage regular physical activity they enjoy, not just organized sports
health.tip4: Model healthy habits yourself - they learn more from what you do than what you say

friendships.title: Navigating Changing Friendships
friendships.description: Social relationships become more complex during puberty
friendships.tip1: Validate that friendship changes and losses are painful and normal
friendships.tip2: Help them distinguish between healthy and unhealthy friendships
friendships.tip3: Resist the urge to fix friend problems - guide them to solve issues themselves
friendships.tip4: Keep lines of communication open about who they're spending time with

peerPressure.title: Handling Peer Pressure
peerPressure.description: Equip your child with tools to resist negative influences
peerPressure.tip1: Role-play scenarios so they practice saying 'no' before facing real pressure
peerPressure.tip2: Give them an 'out': Let them blame you ('My parents will kill me')
peerPressure.tip3: Discuss the difference between fitting in and changing who they are
peerPressure.tip4: Build confidence in their own values and decision-making abilities

boundaries.title: Teaching Personal Boundaries
boundaries.description: Help your child understand and communicate boundaries
boundaries.tip1: Teach them that their body is theirs - they control who touches it and how
boundaries.tip2: Respect their need for privacy (knocking, not reading diaries, etc.)
boundaries.tip3: Model setting your own boundaries with others
boundaries.tip4: Make it clear they can always tell you if someone makes them uncomfortable

onlineSafety.title: Digital Safety During Puberty
onlineSafety.description: Online risks increase as children become more independent
onlineSafety.tip1: Have open conversations about what they're doing online - avoid just monitoring secretly
onlineSafety.tip2: Discuss the permanence of online posts and the concept of digital footprints
onlineSafety.tip3: Talk about the difference between online personas and reality (including unrealistic bodies)
onlineSafety.tip4: Set clear rules about sharing personal information and photos online

personalSpace.title: Respecting Privacy Needs
personalSpace.description: Balance their need for privacy with your need to keep them safe
personalSpace.tip1: Knock before entering their room - physical privacy builds trust
personalSpace.tip2: Don't read diaries or texts unless you have serious safety concerns
personalSpace.tip3: Create privacy for bathroom and dressing while staying available for questions
personalSpace.tip4: Explain that privacy is a privilege that comes with responsibility and honesty

books.title: Recommended Books & Materials
books.description: Quality resources to supplement your conversations
books.tip1: Age-appropriate books about puberty to leave where your child can read privately
books.tip2: Consider books specific to your child's gender identity and body
books.tip3: Online resources from reputable sources (medical organizations, schools)
books.tip4: This app's interactive games and activities make learning engaging

professional.title: When to Seek Professional Help
professional.description: Sometimes expert guidance is needed - and that's okay
professional.tip1: Pediatrician visits around ages 9-11 for puberty discussions
professional.tip2: Therapist if emotional struggles persist or intensify
professional.tip3: School counselor for social or academic concerns
professional.tip4: Support groups for parents navigating similar challenges

keyPrinciples.title: Core Principles for Parenting Through Puberty

patience.title: Patience is Everything
patience.description: This phase is temporary. Your child will make mistakes, say hurtful things, and test boundaries. Stay steady - your calm consistency is their anchor during this storm.

communication.title: Keep Talking
communication.description: Even when they seem uninterested or push you away, keep showing up. Brief check-ins, notes, texts - find ways to stay connected that work for them.

safety.title: Safety First, Always
safety.description: Trust is important, but so is safety. It's okay to monitor, ask questions, and set boundaries. Being the 'cool parent' is less important than being the protective one.

support.title: Unconditional Love
support.description: No matter how challenging this phase gets, remind your child regularly that your love is unwavering. They need to know they can't lose your love by growing up.

emergency.title: When to Seek Immediate Help
emergency.description: If your child exhibits any of these signs, don't hesitate - get professional help immediately:
emergency.point1: Any mention of self-harm, suicide, or hurting others
emergency.point2: Sudden, dramatic personality changes or complete withdrawal
emergency.point3: Signs of abuse (physical marks, extreme fear, inappropriate sexual knowledge)

changes.title: Understanding Your Child's Changes
changes.subtitle: Learn what your child is experiencing physically and emotionally üåü

growth.title: Growth Spurts
growth.description: Children grow at different rates. Growth spurts can be rapid and awkward.

bodyShape.title: Body Shape Changes
bodyShape.description: Body develops new proportions and curves as they mature.

voice.title: Voice Changes
voice.description: Voice may deepen or change in pitch - especially in boys.

skin.title: Skin Changes
skin.description: Acne and oily skin are common. Good hygiene helps manage this.

hair.title: Hair Growth
hair.description: New hair grows in underarms, pubic area, and on face (boys).

odor.title: Body Odor
odor.description: Increased sweating requires daily deodorant use.

mood.title: Mood Swings
mood.description: Hormonal changes cause real emotional volatility - it's biological.

interests.title: New Interests
interests.description: Children develop new hobbies, passions, and interests.

independence.title: Independence
independence.description: They'll want more privacy and independence from family.

relationships.title: Relationships
relationships.description: Friendships and romantic interests become more important.

awareness.title: Self-Awareness
awareness.description: They think more about identity and who they want to become.

confidence.title: Confidence Challenges
confidence.description: Self-esteem often dips during puberty - they need reassurance.

remember.title: Important Reminders for Parents üåà
remember.timing: Timing: Puberty can start ages 8-14. Every child is unique - don't compare!
remember.pace: Pace: Some changes happen quickly, others take years. Be patient.
remember.support: Support: Keep communication open. Your child needs to know you're available for any questions or concerns.

diary.title: Your Child's Feelings Diary
diary.subtitle: A private space for your child to track and express their emotions üìù
diary.placeholder: What's on your mind? Share your thoughts, feelings, or what happened today...
diary.noEntries: No entries yet. Start by adding your first one! üí≠

tips.title: üí° Diary Tips for Your Child
tips.regular: ‚ú® Write regularly - even just a few sentences helps!
tips.honest: üéØ Be honest about feelings - this is a private space
tips.lookback: üåà Look back at old entries to see growth over time
tips.valid: üí™ Remember: all feelings are valid and normal

remember.title: Remember: Every Child is Unique üåà
remember.timing: ‚è∞ Timing: Changes can start ages 8-14 and continue into late teens.
remember.variation: üìè Variation: There's NO single 'normal' - everyone develops differently!
remember.questions: üí¨ Questions? Encourage your child to talk with you, their doctor, or a trusted adult.
remember.health: üè• Health: If something causes pain or worries your child, consult a healthcare provider.

team.appreciationTitle: Thank You For Being Part of Our Story
team.appreciationMessage: Parenting Hub is a living project that grows with families like yours. Your feedback, courage, and curiosity inspire every update we build. We‚Äôre cheering you on‚Äîalways.
